rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 21   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 20   Value: 11
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 16   Value: 15
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 24   Value: 29
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 8    Value: 36
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
Okay, let me carefully work out what would be most profitable.

My current asset values
– Wheat: 126
– Wood: 220
– Sheep: 240
– Brick: 696
– Ore: 288  
Total = 1 570

I value every resource strictly by the individual-unit value, so:
• I’m willing to give away Wheat most cheaply (6 each)  
• Wood (11) and Sheep (15) are still below Brick  
• Brick (29) is the most valuable material I own  
• Ore (36) is the single best card, so I’ll try hard *not* to lose it entirely.

Opportunities  
1) I have 24 Brick: I can spare some without hurting my supply.  
2) I’d like to convert my low-end stuff into more high-end stuff.  
3) Ore is scarce for me (only 8) and also the highest value; if I’m forced to part with a couple to land more Brick I’ll do it, but I’d rather not shed the last ones.

Opening offer that is strictly value-positive *for me* and still seems reasonable for the rival  
Offer: I give 4 Wheat (4×6 = 24), 3 Sheep (3×15 = 45), 1 Ore (36) for 5 Brick (5×29 = 145).  
Net value I receive: 145 - 24 - 45 - 36 = 40 points gain.  
For my opponent, 4 Wheat + 3 Sheep + 1 Ore is probably a decent haul; 5 Brick is expensive but not outrageous.

So my first message is:

[Offer: 4 Wheat, 3 Sheep, 1 Ore -> 5 Brick]

rounds.response:
Looking at my valuation, the key point is that Brick is by far my highest-value resource (29). I have plenty of it (24 units), and apparently Player 1 doesn’t want to give any up—my attempt to gain 5 more Brick was rejected.

To boost my total value, I should aim to increase my holdings of either Brick (highest marginal value) or Ore (next-highest), while giving away goods that are *less* valuable to me per unit. I have excess Wheat (6 value) and excess Sheep (15 value), so I’ll try to obtain more Brick or Ore with those commodities.

[Offer: 5 Wheat, 3 Sheep, 1 Ore -> 5 Brick, 1 Ore]

rounds.response:
Player 0 did not make an offer, so I evaluate my position and make an offer.
My current resources:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 6    Value: 5
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 5    Value: 8
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 19   Value: 17
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 12   Value: 27
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 24   Value: 37

I exchanged 5 Sheep and 1 Ore for 1 Brick.
Value of 5 Sheep: 5 * 17 = 85
Value of 1 Ore: 1 * 37 = 37
Total value given: 85 + 37 = 122

Value of 1 Brick: 1 * 27 = 27
Total value received: 27

My net value decreased. This was a bad trade. I need to be more careful.
It looks like I'm trying to get Brick, which is a good resource, but I'm overpaying. I should aim for more balanced trades.
I should try to offload some of my high quantity/low value items for higher value items, or simply make sure the value of what I get is more than what I give.

What I want: More Brick (Value 27) and Ore (Value 37).
What I have a lot of: Sheep (Qty 19, Value 17).
What I have some of: Wheat (Qty 6, Value 5), Wood (Qty 5, Value 8), Brick (Qty 12, Value 27), Ore (Qty 24, Value 37).

Let's try to trade Sheep for Brick again, but with better value.

I want to get 1 Brick (Value 27).
How much Sheep should I offer for it?
1 Sheep is 17.
2 Sheep would be 34. This is a bit much, but it's closer to the value of a Brick than 1 Sheep.
If I offer 2 Sheep for 1 Brick:
Value given: 2 * 17 = 34
Value received: 1 * 27 = 27
Still a loss.

What if I offer 1 Sheep and some Wheat?
1 Sheep (17) + 2 Wheat (10) = 27. Perfectly balanced. That's a good trade if Player 0 accepts it.

Another idea is to trade some of my excess Ore for something valuable I can then flip for Brick. Or just simple trades for things I need.

Let's re-evaluate what I have:
Wheat: 6 (Value 5)
Wood: 5 (Value 8)
Sheep: 19 (Value 17)
Brick: 12 (Value 27)
Ore: 24 (Value 37)

I have plenty of Sheep and Ore. I want more Brick.

Let's try:
Offer: 2 Sheep -> 1 Brick. Value: 34 -> 27. Loss.
Offer: 1 Sheep, 2 Wheat -> 1 Brick. Value: 27 -> 27. Even. This is a good offer!

Let me consider what Player 0 might need. If Player 0 is also trying to get Brick, then this offer might not be good for them.
However, I can only assume Player 0 is also trying to increase their total value.

I will try for the balanced trade this time.

[Offer: 1 Sheep, 2 Wheat -> 1 Brick]

rounds.response:
My status  
Resource    | Qty after last accepted trade | Value Qty×Value | Remaining trade-options
---|---:|---:|---:  
Brick       | 23  | 667   | 0 (I will keep at least 5 Brick)
Ore         | 7   | 252   | Up to 2 more Ore
Sheep       | 22  | 330   | Up to 13 more Sheep
Wheat       | 21  | 126   | Up to 16 more Wheat
Wood        | 20  | 220   | Up to 17 more Wood

Incoming proposal (from Player 1): 1 Sheep + 2 Wheat → 1 Brick  
- Value offered to me: 1×15 + 2×6 = 27  
- Value requested from me: 1×29 = 29  
Net loss to me = 2 value  
Since Brick is already my most valuable stock and I don’t want to drop below 23, I refuse this.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
My new inventory after the last accepted trade (I gave 1 Brick, received 5 Sheep + 1 Ore) is:

- Wheat 21, value 6 → 126  
- Wood  20, value 11 → 220  
- Sheep 12, value 15 → 180   (16-5+1 accepted)  
- Brick 23, value 29 → 667   (24-1+0)  
- Ore     9, value 36 → 324  

Now Player 1 is offering 2 Wheat + 1 Sheep for 1 Brick.

Value I would send: 29 (1 Brick)  
Value I would receive: 6 × 2 + 15 × 1 = 12 + 15 = 27  

The trade is a net-loss for me by 2 value-points, and it further reduces my Brick count (Brick is my highest-value resource at 29).  
Therefore I will not accept.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let's step back and see what’s happened so far:

Current situation (my holdings after the 2 Brick → 5 Sheep + 1 Ore swap)  

Inventory recap  
- Wheat: 25 (was 21, none dealt away, none gained so far)  
- Wood: 20  
- Sheep: 21 (16 + 2 − 3 + 5)  (5 Sheep gained in the 1 Brick deal)  
- Brick: 22 (24 − 1 − 1)  
- Ore: 9  (8 − 1 − 0 (because I immediately got 1 back in the swap))  

Value recap (using the values I personally assign to my own copies of each):

- Wheat: 25 × 6  = 150  
- Wood: 20 × 11 = 220  
- Sheep: 21 × 15 = 315  
- Brick: 22 × 29 = 638  
- Ore: 9 × 36   = 324  

Total value right now: 1,647

Player 1 just repeated the exact same 2 Wheat, 1 Sheep → 1 Brick offer the third time in a row.  
Each prior time I judged that deal worth –29 total value to me ( I give up 29 Brick value, receive 12 Wheat + 15 Sheep = 27 value → net –2). That hasn’t changed.

There’s only one turn left in the game (turn 10). Accepting this last offer would still cost me 2 value points, and I’m focused on maximizing my end-game total. So:

[Deny]

0.reason: Player 0 won by having a larger gain in inventory value.

1.reason: Player 0 won by having a larger gain in inventory value.
